Module MathUtils
Package mathUtils.calculus.complex

Interface ComplexFunction

Functional Interface:
This is a functional interface and can therefore be used as the assignment target for a lambda expression or method reference.
@Experimental
@FunctionalInterface
public interface ComplexFunction

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    default ComplexFunction derivative()
    Computes the derivative of this function.
    default boolean isContinuousAt​(java.lang.Number a)

  • Method Details

    • mandelbrot

      static ComplexFunction mandelbrot​(int error)
      Returns a complex function that represents the famous mandelbrot set. Since it is a fractal, the set can be found within itself an infinite amount of time. Therefore, a parameter describes when the set should converge.
      Parameters:
      error - Number of times to reiterate
      Returns:
      A complex function representing the mandelbrot set

    • mandelbrot

      static ComplexFunction mandelbrot()
      Returns a complex function that represents the famous mandelbrot set. Since it is a fractal, the set can be found within itself an infinite amount of time. Here, the function converges after 1000 iterations. This method delegates to: mandelbrot(1000).
      Returns:
      A complex function representing the mandelbrot set

    • z

      java.lang.Number z​(java.lang.Number c)
      The actual function. This function is described as: \( f:A \to B \). The domain and co-domain are represented by instances of Number. The intention is to allow versatility between real, imaginary and complex numbers.
      For example, to create a function
      \( f(z) = \sin(z) + i \cos(z); \; f:\mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C} \)
      Write:
      ComplexFunction f = z -> ComplexMath.add( ComplexMath.cos(z), new Imaginary( ComplexMath.sin(z).doubleValue() ) );
      Parameters:
      c - The functionÂ´s input
      Returns:
      The functionÂ´s output

    • isContinuousAt

      default boolean isContinuousAt​(java.lang.Number a)
      Returns whether this function is continuous at the given number a. A complex function \( f \) is said to be continuous at a given point \( a \) if the limit
      \( \lim\limits_{z \to a} \dfrac{ f(z) - f(a) }{ z - a } \)
      exists. Here, \( a \) is chosen to be a very small value: MathTools.INFINITESIMAL.
      Parameters:
      a - The number to evaluate if this function is continuous at
      Returns:
      Whether or not this function is continuous at the given number

    • derivative

      default ComplexFunction derivative()
      Computes the derivative of this function. The derivative of a complex function \( f(z) \) that is continuous at a point \( a \) is given by:

      \( fÂ´(a) = \lim\limits_{z \to a} \dfrac{ f(z) - f(a) }{ z - a } \)

      Note that if the function is not continuous at the given point, then Complex.isNaN( f1.z(a) ) returns true.
